header.title: The Onion
header.subtitle: the aspiring montage
header.lead: Onion game is a series a scenes with no real connection. For each scene that is played, we add layers to the metaphorical onion.

props.string:
Starts out with one player on stage playing a scene.

After a while, a new player enters the stage -- bringing a new scene with him. They now play in this new scene, with totally new characters. With enough time a third player enters the stage, prompting yet another scene -- now with three brand new characters.

When all players involved in the game are on stage and have played the last scene, we start to peel back the onion, layer by layer. The last player to join finds a reason to leave the scene. And as he does, we continue the next-to-last scene with its corresponding characters. The character that originally established that scene finds a reason to leave -- and once again we pick up from the scene before that with its characters and corresponding player count.

The game is over when we’re back to one person on stage, and that character concludes his scene.

image.text: A perfect example of how an onion might look like

props.string: Difficult scene to explain, but fun to play. Usually has a logistical limit of 6 or 7 players. Requires players to play colorful and bold characters. Players have to coordinate, not to steal too much spotlight as the player count rises. Introduces an interesting shift in dynamics between the different player counts. One player is vastly different to two players; two players is vastly different to three players, etc.

header.title: New Choice
header.subtitle: or: how to quickly get somewhere
header.lead: New choice sees players through a regular scene, but one where the director at any time can ask the improvisers to change what they just did or said.

props.string: It’s a game about justification. For three players. One director instructs two players to play out a scene. During the scene, the director will challenge players to change their previous verbal, emotional or physical response.

Works best when the scene gets a minute to establish a platform without interruption, and where the players try not to go overboard with absurdity. Requires players to make bold choices that strive to move the story forward. These are the funniest to intercept and change. Director needs to have a sense of moderation -- let the players justify the choices you’ve put them through, and try not to go overboard with stringing new choices until the end. Build-up.
